Austin Frank
I publish “Today in Politics” and write about current events. Fmr. Hill staffer.
Apr 13

Russia Could Beat us in World War III

Recent comments by Russia over America’s missile strike against Syria’s Assad regime indicate that, at the very least, the Kremlin is not afraid of threatening us with force. World War III is not so unthinkable anymore as the US and Russia edge closer to confrontation over Syria.

At the very least, the contours of a future World War III are starting to take form. For instance, there is little doubt the US and Russia will be adversaries, and the central players in the conflict. From there, it would be a matter of the nations further down the global pecking order choosing sides. Western Europe would ultimately side with the US, and Russia would appeal to former Soviet Bloc states.

So all this begs the question: who would win?

I must stress that I’m not saying World War III is imminent. Though America and Russia are in an alarming game of brinkmanship over Syria and are as close to war as we’ve ever been since the Cold War, our two nations still maintain diplomatic relations. US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson visited Moscow just yesterday, and though he and his Russian counterpart Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov didn’t agree on much, the fact that the visit happened in the first place shows that as bad as relations are, they’re not nearly as bad as they could be. If and when the US and Russia break off diplomatic relations, then war becomes a not only possible but probable.

What I’m saying is that in a future World War III, whenever it happens, the Russians have a far greater shot at beating us than most people think.

First, a disclaimer: we’re the richest, most technologically advanced nation on earth and our military is, even in its deteriorated state, still undeniably the strongest in the world. Plus, we have James “If you f**k with me, I’ll kill you all” Mattis in charge of the whole thing. We would be prohibitive favorites in any war we go into.

But just because we have a superior fighting force doesn’t mean we’re guaranteed to win. Plenty of underdogs have won wars in the past. This country was born when a ragtag group of colonists, aided by the French, took on and beat a superior British Army. More recently, fighting in the dense jungles and foreign terrain of Vietnam, the US military became embroiled in an unwinnable war against an undermanned, undersupplied band of guerrillas who had home-turf advantage and the inherent desperation and passion that comes with fighting foreign invaders on your own soil. The Viet Cong simply cared more about the war, and had more to lose than the American side. They knew what they were fighting for, while the Americans really didn’t.

In war, there must be a major moral and/or patriotic call to arms. There must be passion among the people, the idea that the war is a “just cause.” Making the Japanese pay after Pearl Harbor, and stopping Hitler, made World War II a just war, a necessary war in the eyes of most Americans. Vietnam, on the other hand, was not: most Americans probably had never even heard of Vietnam prior to the mid-1960s; what were we going to war there for, anyway? In a war, the side that’s hearts are in it have an inherent advantage over the side that is reluctant and indifferent.

Russia Has the Emotional Edge

This is the main advantage Russia would have over us in a future conflict: Russians have a chip on their shoulder. Russia has something to prove, something to gain. Putin could probably get easy wins early in Eastern Europe, and gobble up former Soviet states. That’s an incentive for him. He might even go after Turkey, a NATO ally of ours, and attempt to annex the Bosphorus and secure their safe maritime passage to the Mediterranean.

Beyond that, Russia, as the head of the Soviet Union, suffered an embarrassment when the Cold War ended and their communist dreams crumbled. Russian leaders, many of whom grew up during the Cold War, are determined to regain their nation’s former glory, prestige, influence and power, and they have a reason to hold a grudge against America to boot.

On top of this, Russia, with its economy in decline due to lower oil prices, might see wartime mobilization as a possible economic boon.

Us, on the other hand: we have nothing to gain. We have it all already. There’s no lost territory to regain, no prestige and glory to win back.

We have everything to lose. Americans would look at the prospect of a World War III — which would be the most devastating conflict in human history, no doubt, with the specter of nuclear weapons hanging over the whole thing — as having very little, if any, upside. What do we gain from it? How would it make our lives measurably better? It wouldn’t. It would make things measurably worse in almost every way. So Americans would be deeply resistant to such a conflict.

After 9/11, American men were tripping over themselves to enlist in the army and go over to the Middle East and make the terrorists pay. Pearl Harbor was another similar nationwide call to arms to respond to foreign aggression. Unless Russia struck the US mainland before war was ever declared, how could Americans be galvanized into wanting to fight them?

Most young men in this country don’t want war with the Russians. I’m not saying we’ve “gone soft”. I’m talking about the fact that, unlike the Boomers and even the older end of Gen X, my generation didn’t grow up during the Cold War. We didn’t truly grow up with that seething animosity for the Russians. Sure, we’ve all seen Rocky IV and know, intuitively, that Russia was our bitter rival for most of the 20th century and that we should view them as such even today, but my generation doesn’t truly grasp that. The Russians have never done anything to us to make us hate them.

In addition, we are a war-weary nation. We’ve been involved in the Middle East for almost 16 years now. Very few Americans are clamoring for war. Barack Obama got elected in 2008 in large part because he was harshly critical of the Iraq War and vowed to end it quickly. A significant portion of Donald Trump’s base likes him because he has been critical of the idea of gratuitous foreign adventures, “America First.” Vietnam is still within living memory, too, and that contributes to the general war-weariness.

Most Americans have no concept of a world in which we’re not the most powerful nation. We take for granted the fact that we are the straw that stirs the world’s drink. The prospect of winning glory on the battlefield does not tantalize Americans. As a people, we don’t really have a hope for a better future on this earth, as that future has been our reality for a long while now (probably since at least the 1950s). We take our comfortable, secure, largely want-free lives for granted. We’re a materialistic society, and as such most Americans’ goals have nothing to do with the nation itself, but instead on buying a new car, a new house, taking a vacation, seeing their sports team win a championship, watching kids grow up, etc. How can a world war benefit typical Americans, obsessed as we are with entertainment and consumerism? We’re a leisure culture; most Americans put little thought to the troubles and happenings in the world beyond our shores.

We, as a people, are not ready at all.

And for all the talk about Donald Trump’s “nationalism”, there isn’t a lot of itching for war to accompany it. Trumpian Nationalism isn’t so much a macho, saber-rattling jingoism but a backlash against globalization — it’s an economic manifesto rather than a militaristic one. American glory is not to be won on the battlefield but at the negotiating table hashing out favorable trade deals, and putting up protectionist walls around American industries that have fallen on hard times. Nationalism Trump-style is not about showing rival nations how powerful we are militarily, but rather a revolt against the globalized economy and the exodus of American jobs.

The China Factor

Until now, we’ve said nothing about the elephant in the room: China. China is the second largest economy, and the second most powerful nation on earth. China’s entry into a WW3 could decisively tip the scales to one side. So the question is, who would China align with, America or Russia? There are two competing theories here: the first is that China would prefer the US to emerge victorious because the US is China’s largest trading partner. Our dollars are China’s economic lifeblood: we spend so much money on Chinese goods that their economy could collapse if we went to war with them.

But what if China became convinced that aligning with Russia could result in it becoming the preeminent superpower on earth? We know that’s China’s goal (there’s a book on this, The Hundred Year Marathon, that is simply a must-read). We know the Chinese eagerly await the day when their nation surpasses the US as the world’s superpower, the apex nation. Perhaps they see entering WW3 against the US as a way to make that goal come to fruition sooner rather than later. If China were to emerge victorious in WW3, they’d be the world’s top nation. The prospect could be too enticing to resist.

We’re not far and away #1 in the world now. The gap between us and the next most powerful nations is narrowing, and has been for most of the 21st century. Our grip on World’s Superpower Status grows more tenuous seemingly every year as we stagnate and other rivals grow. This is Credit Suisse’s ranking of world militaries:

We have the ability to take on Russia and China individually. But Russia and China together? Forget it.

While I’m not saying the Russians and Chinese are itching to go to war with us, I am saying they’d have more to gain from the war than we would, and as such they’d fight with more gusto. The Russians and the Chinese have something to prove, and we largely do not.

Sometimes it so happens that the fight comes to you whether you want it or not. In a future World War III, America is likely to be the reluctant warrior, and that is a recipe for disaster.

That is, unless Russia did something to really piss us off, like launch an attack on our mainland and kill civilians or, God forbid, nuke us. That would wake the sleeping giant. An American public fully and emotionally invested in the war changes the game completely.
